Product Development.step: Build a minimum viable product to test your idea quickly
Product Development.Real-life example: Airbnb launched with a single listing, allowing the founders to test their idea and gather feedback before scaling up

Product Development.step: Ship your product to customers before it's fully polished and charge money for it
Product Development.Real-life example: Dropbox launched a beta version of its cloud storage service, allowing users to pay for additional storage and providing valuable feedback for improvement

Product Development.step: Change your product constantly based on customer feedback and experimentation
Product Development.Real-life example: Netflix constantly updates its user interface and content offerings based on user behavior and feedback, leading to a highly personalized experience

Product Development.step: Run experiments on your customers to validate your product and overall vision
Product Development.Real-life example: Amazon regularly runs A/B tests on its website, trying out different layouts, features, and recommendations to optimize the user experience and increase sales

Product Development.step: Use the Build-Measure-Learn feedback loop to turn ideas into products and learn from customer responses
Product Development.Real-life example: Airbnb used this loop to develop its platform, starting with a simple air mattress rental service and iterating based on user feedback to become a global accommodations marketplace

Product Development.step: Use a minimum viable product to test leap-of-faith assumptions and iterate on your product
Product Development.Real-life example: Dropbox released a minimum viable product as a video showcasing its potential, which helped the company gauge interest and refine its product before launching the full version

Decision Making.step: Use a scientific approach to making decisions and measuring progress
Decision Making.Real-life example: Google uses data-driven decision making, relying on metrics such as user engagement and click-through rates to inform product development and marketing strategies

Decision Making.step: Implement a new accounting system to evaluate progress and decide whether to pivot or persevere
Decision Making.Real-life example: Intuit implemented a new accounting system to track key metrics and make data-driven decisions, allowing the company to pivot its strategy and focus on high-growth areas

Customer Feedback and Innovation.step: Focus on what customers want without directly asking them
Customer Feedback and Innovation.Real-life example: Apple observes customer behavior and preferences, using this information to design innovative products like the iPhone and iPad that meet unmet needs

Customer Feedback and Innovation.step: Apply lean thinking to the process of innovation to reduce waste and increase efficiency
Customer Feedback and Innovation.Real-life example: Toyota applies lean principles to its product development process, eliminating waste and maximizing value for customers through continuous improvement and iteration

Customer Feedback and Innovation.step: Conduct frequent experiments to test elements of your vision and validate learning scientifically
Customer Feedback and Innovation.Real-life example: Amazon conducts frequent A/B testing experiments to validate new features and products, such as its 1-Click ordering button, which was tested and refined based on customer feedback

Customer Feedback and Innovation.step: Adopt innovation accounting to measure progress, set up milestones, and prioritize work
Customer Feedback and Innovation.Real-life example: Google uses innovation accounting to measure the progress of its innovative projects, such as Google X, and prioritize work based on key metrics and milestones

Mindset and Approach.step: Embrace a growth mindset, focusing on learning and improvement
Mindset and Approach.Real-life example: Microsoft's CEO, Satya Nadella, prioritizes a growth mindset, encouraging employees to learn from failures and experiment with new ideas

Mindset and Approach.step: Prioritize experimentation and learning over perfection
Mindset and Approach.Real-life example: Facebook's early motto was 'Move Fast and Break Things,' reflecting a mindset that prioritizes rapid experimentation and learning over perfection

Mindset and Approach.step: Apply the Lean Startup principles to your business to improve success rates
Mindset and Approach.Real-life example: Instagram applied Lean Startup principles to its development, rapidly iterating and refining its product based on user feedback to become a successful and widely-used social media platform

Mindset and Approach.step: Focus on validated learning to build a sustainable business, rather than just making products or money
Mindset and Approach.Real-life example: Warby Parker focuses on validated learning, using customer feedback and data to inform its product development and marketing strategies, and build a sustainable and socially responsible business model
